plants.description: Romanesco cabbage (Romanesco broccoli / Romanesco cauliflower): biennial grown as annual. Compact conical inflorescence with fractal patterns, bright green color. Possible confusions: other broccolis and cauliflowers. No documented case of confusion with similar toxic plant. Recommended soil: fertile, silty-clay or silty-sandy, well drained, rich in organic matter, good water retention without waterlogging. Optimal pH 6.0–7.5 (neutral to slightly alkaline). Exposure: full sun, tolerates light partial shade in hot summer.

watering.frequency: After transplanting: every 1–2 days for 1–2 weeks depending on climate; then: deep waterings every 2–4 days, more frequent in hot or windy period
watering.method: At base, slow and deep watering; avoid wetting heads and foliage (drip, soaker hoses, furrows advised)

thinning.distance: 50 cm between plants, 50–60 cm between rows
thinning.when: Transplanting recommended at 4–5 true leaves stage (robust non-spindly plants); controlled spacing and strong root system

weeding.recommendation: Mulching advised (straw, hay, dead leaves, dried grass, mature compost): limits evaporation and crusting, regulates temperature, reduces weeds; avoid too fresh mulch conducive to slugs

culturalTips: Time to maturity: 75–100 days after transplanting; 100–120 days after sowing
Sowing (temperate climate): under cover late Feb–April; transplanting March–May; summer sowing for autumn/winter harvest: May–July depending on climate; transplanting 4–6 weeks after sowing
Emergence conditions: fine substrate, well drained, moist without soaking; soil temperature 15–24°C; good aeration; indirect light; avoid surface drying
Blocking factors: soil crusting (avoid violent watering), substrate dryness, excess water (asphyxia, damping off), temperatures >27°C (irregular germination; early bolting later)

Natural fertilization: mature compost at bottom 3–5 kg/m² + light boosters; diluted nettle manure (nitrogen) and comfrey manure (K) at base; green manures possible: legumes, phacelia, cereal–legume mixes
Rotation: return of Brassicaceae on same bed after 3–4 years; avoid brassicaceae as immediate predecessor/successor (clubroot and specific pests)
Clubroot prevention: avoid acidic soils (pH<6), excess moisture and too short rotations; maintain pH close to 7 (compost + mild liming amendments if needed)
Pest protection: insect-proof nets/fleece (cabbage whites, cabbage fly, flea beetles); collars at removal (cabbage fly); beer traps/shelter traps (slugs)

preparations: Comfrey manure (flowering support and head firmness; K inputs)
Horsetail decoction (fungal disease prevention; tissue strengthening)
Diluted black soap / organic insecticidal soap (against aphids; targeted application)
beneficialInsects: Lacewings (larvae) against aphids and small pests
Parasitoid wasps (parasitism of cabbage white caterpillars)

plants.harvestTime: 75–100 days after transplanting; 100–120 days after sowing depending on variety and climate. Signs: compact conical head, well-formed fractal patterns, bright green, closed flower buds (no small yellow flowers). Harvest: cut under head with clean knife, leave a few protective leaves; preferably in morning in cool weather. Regrowth: mainly a single head, few or no useful side shoots (limited regrowth). Storage: refrigerator 0–4°C 3–7 days (perforated bag); freezing after blanching 2–3 min then cooling (several months); lacto-fermentation possible (exact times not documented).

avoid: other brassicaceae (cabbage, cauliflower, kale, turnip, radish, mustard)
nitrogen-hungry crops with strong development (corn, large cucurbits, tomatoes in poor soil)
